column2: He told his mother that he and his betrothed had parted; but he would tell no more.

column2: I suppose I _must_ be satisfied, Clement, she said.

column2: Clement went back to London.

column2: His life seemed to have altogether slipped away from him, and he felt like an old man who has lost all the bright chances of existence; the hope of domestic happiness and a pleasant home; the opportunity of a useful career and an honoured name; and who has nothing more to do but to wait patiently till the slow current of his empty life drops into the sea of death.
column3: His life seemed to have altogether slipped away from him, and he felt like an old man who has lost all the bright chances of existence; the hope of domestic happiness and a pleasant home; the opportunity of a useful career and an honoured name; and who has nothing more to do but to wait patiently till the slow current of his empty life drops into the sea of death.

column2: I feel so old, mother, he said, sometimes; "I feel so old."
column3: I feel so old, mother, he said, sometimes; "I feel so old."

column2: To a man who has been accustomed to be busy there is no affliction so intolerable as idleness.
column3: To a man who has been accustomed to be busy there is no affliction so intolerable as idleness.

column2: Clement Austin felt this, and yet he had no heart to begin life again, though tempting offers came to him from great commercial houses, whose chiefs were eager to secure the well-known cashier of Messrs.

column2: Poor Clement could not go into the world yet.

column2: He wasted hour after hour, and day after day, in gloomy thoughts about the past.

column2: What a dupe he had been! what a shallow, miserable fool! for he had believed as firmly in Margaret Wilmot's truth, as he had believed in the blue sky above his head.
column3: What a dupe he had been! what a shallow, miserable fool! for he had believed as firmly in Margaret Wilmot's truth, as he had believed in the blue sky above his head.

column2: One day a new idea flashed into Clement Austin's mind; an idea which placed Margaret Wilmot's character even in a worse light than that in which she had revealed herself in her own confession.
column3: One day a new idea flashed into Clement Austin's mind; an idea which placed Margaret Wilmot's character even in a worse light than that in which she had revealed herself in her own confession.

column2: There could be only one reason for the sudden change in her sentiments about Henry Dunbar: the millionaire had bribed her to silence!
column3: There could be only one reason for the sudden change in her sentiments about Henry Dunbar: the millionaire had bribed her to silence!

column2: This girl, who seemed the very incarnation of purity and candour, had her price, perhaps, as well as other people, and Henry Dunbar had bought the silence of his victim's daughter.
column3: This girl, who seemed the very incarnation of purity and candour, had her price, perhaps, as well as other people, and Henry Dunbar had bought the silence of his victim's daughter.

column2: The longer Clement thought of the subject, the more certainly he arrived at the conclusion that Margaret Wilmot had been, either bribed or frightened into silence by Henry Dunbar.

column2: It might be that the banker had terrified this unhappy girl by some awful threat that had preyed upon her mind, and driven her from the man who loved her, whom she loved perhaps, in spite of those heartless words which she had spoken in the bitter hour of their parting.

column2: Again and again he went over the same ground, trying to find some lurking circumstance, no matter how unlikely in its nature, which should explain and justify Margaret's conduct.

column2: Sometimes in his dreams he saw the familiar face looking at him with pensive, half-reproachful glances; and then a dark figure that was strange to him came between him and that gentle shadow, and thrust the vision away with a ruthless hand.
column3: Sometimes in his dreams he saw the familiar face looking at him with pensive, half reproachful glances; and then a dark figure that was strange to him came between him and that gentle shadow, and thrust the vision away with a ruthless hand.

column2: At last, by dint of going over the ground again and again, always pleading Margaret's cause against the stern witness of cruel facts, Clement came to look upon the girl's innocence as a settled thing.
column3: At last, by dint of going over the ground again and again, always pleading Margaret's cause against the stern witness of cruel facts, Clement came to look upon the girl's innocence as a settled thing.

column2: There was falsehood and treachery in the business, but Margaret Wilmot was neither false nor treacherous.

column2: There was a mystery, and Henry Dunbar was at the bottom of it.

column2: It seems as if the spirit of the murdered man troubled our lives, and cried to us for vengeance, Clement thought.

column2: There will be no peace for us until the secret of the deed done in the grove near Winchester has been brought to light.

column2: This thought, working night and day in Clement Austin's brain, gave rise to a fixed resolve.
column3: This thought, working night and day in Clement Austin's brain, gave rise to a fixed resolve.

column2: Before he went back to the quiet routine of life, he set himself a task to accomplish, and that task was the solution of the Winchester mystery.
column3: Before he went back to the quiet routine of life, he set himself a task to accomplish, and that task was the solution of the Winchester mystery.

column2: On the very day after this resolution took a definite form, Clement received a letter from Margaret Wilmot.
column3: On the very day after this resolution took a definite form, Clement received a letter from Margaret Wilmot.

column2: The sight of the well-known writing gave him a shock of mingled surprise and hope, and his fingers were faintly tremulous as they tore open the envelope.
column3: The sight of the well-known writing gave him a shock of mingled surprise and hope, and his fingers were faintly tremulous as they tore open the envelope.

column2: The letter was carefully worded, and very brief.
column3: The letter was carefully worded, and very brief.

column2: _You are a good man, Mr. Austin_, Margaret wrote; "_and though you have reason to despise me, I do not think you will refuse to receive my testimony in favour of another who has been falsely suspected of a terrible crime, and who has need of justification.
column3: underscore You are a good man, mr Austin underscore, Margaret wrote; "underscore and though you have reason to despise me, I do not think you will refuse to receive my testimony in favour of another who has been falsely suspected of a terrible crime, and who has need of justification.

column2: Henry Dunbar was not the murderer of my father.
column3: Henry Dunbar was not the murderer of my father.

column2: As Heaven is my witness, this is the truth, and I know it to be the truth.
column3: As Heaven is my witness, this is the truth, and I know it to be the truth.

column2: Let this knowledge content you, and allow the secret of the murder to remain for ever a mystery upon earth, God knows the truth, and has doubtless punished the wretched sinner who was guilty of that crime, as He punishes every other sinner, sooner or later, in the course of His ineffable wisdom.
column3: Let this knowledge content you, and allow the secret of the murder to remain for ever a mystery upon earth, God knows the truth, and has doubtless punished the wretched sinner who was guilty of that crime, as He punishes every other sinner, sooner or later, in the course of His ineffable wisdom.

column2: Leave the sinner, wherever he may be hidden, to the judgment of God, which penetrates every hiding-place; and forget that you have ever known me, or my miserable story._
